paper_title.ja: 平面状伸長火炎における水素添加による希薄燃焼の改善

paper_title.en: Measurement of the burning surface temperature in ammonium perchlorate

description.en:
There are a number of inconsistencies in the measured values reported for the burning surface temperatures of ammonium perchlorate (AP). Therefore, the temperature profile near the burning surface of pure AP was measured using microthermocouples. A pressed AP specimen was burned using a propane/air diffusion flame or by increasing initial temperature below the pressure deflagration limit of AP. Since a small cavity may exist around the thermocouple, a large AP cn stal was grown around the thermocouple bead, and it was also used in the temperature measurement of the burning surface.
A video recording of the AP surface was also made using a charge-coupled dec-ice (CCD) camera during the combustion process. The time on videotape was synchronized with that on the record of die thermocouple measurements using a flash lamp. As a result, the time at which the thermocouple bead appeared on the burning surface was precisely identified on a temperature-time diagram, and the burning surface temperature was obtained.
It was found that the surface temperature of pure AP is in the range of 450-80 degreesC. and it was ascertained that the burning surface temperature is independent of the regression rate and the heating rate of the AP specimen. On the other hand, the surface temperature does depend on pressure. The slope of the logarithmic pressure venus reciprocal surface temperature was 130-160 kJ/mol. This value is slightly higher than one-half of the heat of dissociation for AP. Our results were similar to results obtained by Powling ct al. with an infrared-radiation technique. However, these results are different from those measured by thermocouples in several other studies. These differences may actually reflect differences in the methods used to identify the burning surface in the measured temperature data.

paper_title.ja: 水素添加による高級炭化水素系燃料の希薄燃焼の改善

publication_name.ja: 日本機械学会論文集(B編)

paper_title.en: An Improvement of Lean Combustion Characteristics of Heavy-Hydrocarbon Fuels with Hydrogen Addition

description.en: The Lewis numbers of lean heavy-hydrocarbon fuels are larger than unity, and hence, their flames are prone to extinction in a shear flow, which occurs in a turbulent combustion. Here, propane is used as a representative fuel of heavy-hydrocarbon fuels because the Lewis number of lean propane/air mixtures is larger than unity, and an attempt to improve its combustion characteristics by hydrogen addition has been made. A tubular flame burner is used to evaluate its improvement, since a rotating, streched vortex flow is established in the burner. The results show that with hydrogen additon, the fuel concentration, the flame diameter and the flame temperatuire at extinction are reduced and its combustion characteristics are imporved. However, it is found that the effective equivalence ration at extinction cannot become so small as that of lean methane/air mixture, which has a Lewis number less than unity. © 1999, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B

paper_title.ja: 舶用重油およびエマルジョン燃料を用いたディーゼル噴霧燃焼における点火遅れ
paper_title.en: Ignition Delay of Diesel Spray Combustion Using Marine Diesel Oil and Emulsion Fuel.

description.ja: In order to simulate combustion of emulsion fuel sprays in a marine diesel engine, it is necessary to predict the ignition delay of the spray precisely. Several fuels were tested and a new experimental formula that predicts the ignition delay was developed. This report shows the validity of the formula. A parameter called ignition index is calculated from density and viscosity of a fuel and it represents the ignition characteristics of the fuel. The ignition delay formula is defined by the following parameters : pressure and temperature in the cylinder, concentration of the water in emulsion fuel, and the ignition index. The experimental result shows that the formula predicts the ignition delay considerably well.
description.en: In order to simulate combustion of emulsion fuel sprays in a marine diesel engine, it is necessary to predict the ignition delay of the spray precisely. Several fuels were tested and a new experimental formula that predicts the ignition delay was developed. This report shows the validity of the formula. A parameter called ignition index is calculated from density and viscosity of a fuel and it represents the ignition characteristics of the fuel. The ignition delay formula is defined by the following parameters : pressure and temperature in the cylinder, concentration of the water in emulsion fuel, and the ignition index. The experimental result shows that the formula predicts the ignition delay considerably well.

publication_name.en: TRANSACTIONS OF THE JAPAN SOCIETY OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS Series B

paper_title.en: The phenomena of flame propagation in a rotating tube

description.en: By rotating a tube filled with a premixture, the phenomena of flame propagation in a flow field of rigid-body rotation has been experimentally investigated. Seals at both ends of the tube were taken off and the mixture was fired at one end. Results show that above moderate rational speeds, the flame becomes axisymmetric in shape, and propagates. Flame velocity measurement shows that the flame is accelerated as it moves into the tube, and under the present experimental conditions, a steady-state, constant flame speed has not been achieved. In addition, inherent in an ordinary nonrotating tube, a tulip flame-like phenomenon occurs and the flame is retarded. Another important result is that the propagation limit in rich propane mixtures is unusually extended to the equivalence ratio -3.1 above the standard flammability limit (=2.5). Further detailed measurements were made of the flame velocity and it was found that the flame velocity, Vf, almost linearly increased with increasing rotational speed, N. Based on a simple consideration of momentum balance, and mass continuity across the flame, an analytical expression for the flame velocity was obtained and compared with the experimental results. Good quantitative agreement has been obtained. © 1996 Combustion Institute.

paper_title.en: Tip Opening and Burning Intensity of Bunsen Flames Diluted with Nitrogen

paper_title.ja: 多孔質円筒回転バーナ内に形成された管状火炎の消炎特性
paper_title.en: Extinction Characteristics of Tubular Flames Established in Rotating Burner of Porous Crlinder

description.ja: Extinction characteristics of tubular flames established in a rotating burner of a porous cylinder have been experimentally investigated. The extinction limit was mapped as functions of the fuel concentration (Ω), mixture ejection velocity (V), and burner rotating speed (N). The flame diameter near the extinction limit was also measured. Methane and propane were used as fuels. Results show that the minimum fuel concentration at the lean limit almost independent of V and N, but the maximum fuel concentration at the rich limit depends on V and N. The rich limits decrease as V increase for methane and propane flame, and the rich limit is almost independent of N for the methane flame, but it increases markedly as N increases for the propane flame. The flame diameter at the extinction limits is small for lean-methane and rich-propane flames, but it is large for rich-methane and lean-propane flames. The flame diameter near the extinction limit seems to have the minimum flame diameter under which the flame cannot be established.
description.en: Extinction characteristics of tubular flames established in a rotating burner of a porous cylinder have been experimentally investigated. The extinction limit was mapped as functions of the fuel concentration (Ω), mixture ejection velocity (V), and burner rotating speed (N). The flame diameter near the extinction limit was also measured. Methane and propane were used as fuels. Results show that the minimum fuel concentration at the lean limit almost independent of V and N, but the maximum fuel concentration at the rich limit depends on V and N. The rich limits decrease as V increase for methane and propane flame, and the rich limit is almost independent of N for the methane flame, but it increases markedly as N increases for the propane flame. The flame diameter at the extinction limits is small for lean-methane and rich-propane flames, but it is large for rich-methane and lean-propane flames. The flame diameter near the extinction limit seems to have the minimum flame diameter under which the flame cannot be established.

paper_title.ja: 不活性ガスとの間の対向流伸長予混合火炎の消炎

paper_title.en: Extinction of Stretched Flames in Counterflow between Premixed Mixtures and Inert Gases

description.en: Extinction characteristics of stretched flames established in a stagnation-point flow between premixed mixtures and inert gases have been experimentally investigated. The extinction limit was mapped as a function of fuel concentration and mixture velocity, and the flame location and the maximum flame temperature at the extinction limit have been measured. Methane and propane are used as fuels, and nitrogen, argon, carbon dioxide, and helium are used as inert gases. Results show that the flammable range becomes narrower than that of the adiabatic twin flame, especially for richpropane flames. The flames are extinguished close to the stagnation surface for the lean methane/ air mixture and rich-propane/air mixture, but the flames are extinguished at some distance from the stagnation surface for the rich methane/air mixture and lean propane/air mixture. Such flame behavior at the extinction limit is similar to that of the adiabatic twin flame. The flame temperature at the extinction limit is almost the same for the flames which are extinguished close to the stagnation surface, but different for the flames which are extinguished at a finite distance from the stagnation surface. The flame which is extinguished at a finite distance from the stagnation surface is insensitive to the nature of the stagnation surface. © 1994, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B

paper_title.ja: 窒素で希釈した場合のブンゼン火炎先端の消炎と燃焼強さの変化
paper_title.en: Tip Opening and Burning Intensity of Bunsen Flames Diluted with Nitrogen

description.ja: Tip opening and burning intensity of Bunsen flames diluted with nitrogen have been experimentally investigated. Methane/air and propane/air flames were used in the experiment. The tip opening limit was mapped as a function of the equivalence ratio φ and added nitrogen ratio X, and the tip temperature was measured. Results show that the burning at the tip was intensified in rich flame for methane and lean flame for propane. The maximum allowable dilution by nitrogen also occurs in rich flame (φ=1.05) for methane and lean flame (φ=0.94) for propane. The tip temperature steeply decreases with increasing X on the lean side for methane and the rich side for propane, while it gradually decreases on the rich side for methane and the lean side for propane. These results at the tip were due to the preferential diffusion and nonunity Lewis number through negative stretch induced by flame curvature. The present flame responses to preferential diffusion and Lewis number are ompletely reversed for those of positively stretched stagnation flames.
description.en: Tip opening and burning intensity of Bunsen flames diluted with nitrogen have been experimentally investigated. Methane/air and propane/air flames were used in the experiment. The tip opening limit was mapped as a function of the equivalence ratio φ and added nitrogen ratio X, and the tip temperature was measured. Results show that the burning at the tip was intensified in rich flame for methane and lean flame for propane. The maximum allowable dilution by nitrogen also occurs in rich flame (φ=1.05) for methane and lean flame (φ=0.94) for propane. The tip temperature steeply decreases with increasing X on the lean side for methane and the rich side for propane, while it gradually decreases on the rich side for methane and the lean side for propane. These results at the tip were due to the preferential diffusion and nonunity Lewis number through negative stretch induced by flame curvature. The present flame responses to preferential diffusion and Lewis number are ompletely reversed for those of positively stretched stagnation flames.

paper_title.en: Extinction Characteristics of Tubular Flames Diluted with Nitrogen in a Rotating Stretched Flow Field
Structures of Tubular Flames(Structures of the Tubular Flames of Lean Methane/Air Mixtures in a Rotating Stretched-Flow Field)

paper_title.ja: 管状火炎の構造(第1報,回転伸長流中に形成される希薄メタン-空気火炎の構造
paper_title.en: Structures of tubular flames. 1st Report. Structures of the tubular flames of lean methane/air mixtures in a rotating stretched-flow field.

description.ja: The tulular flames of lean methane/air mixtures in a rotating-flow field have been analyzed for their concentrations of stable species and temperature distributions, and their structures have been investigated. The results show that the tubular flame consists of an inner hot gas core of burned gas and an outer region of the unburned mixture, and that the flame structure is essentially the same as that of the one-dimensional, flat, premixed flame. As the extinction limit is approached, the flame diameter decreases and the concentrations of carbon monoxide and hydrogen behind the flame zone increase. Hence, the extinction of the tubular flame of lean methane/air mixtures is caused by incomplete combustion with stretch as it is with other stretched flames. As the density inside the flame is lower than that outside, the flame front is rendered smooth and cylindrical by the rotational motion of the flow.
description.en: The tulular flames of lean methane/air mixtures in a rotating-flow field have been analyzed for their concentrations of stable species and temperature distributions, and their structures have been investigated. The results show that the tubular flame consists of an inner hot gas core of burned gas and an outer region of the unburned mixture, and that the flame structure is essentially the same as that of the one-dimensional, flat, premixed flame. As the extinction limit is approached, the flame diameter decreases and the concentrations of carbon monoxide and hydrogen behind the flame zone increase. Hence, the extinction of the tubular flame of lean methane/air mixtures is caused by incomplete combustion with stretch as it is with other stretched flames. As the density inside the flame is lower than that outside, the flame front is rendered smooth and cylindrical by the rotational motion of the flow.

paper_title.ja: シャボン玉を利用したプロパン-空気混合気の燃焼速度の測定
paper_title.en: Measurement of the burning velocity of propane-air mixtures using soap bubbles.

description.ja: Experiments have been performed to determine the burning velocity of propane-air mixtures over a wide range of equivalence ratios using soap bubbles and a hot-wire anemometer. This method gives a maximum burning velocity of 50 cm/s at an equivalence ratio of 1.1. The present maximum burning velocity agrees well with the theoretical result predicted by Warnatz. The values of the burning velocity determined in these experiments are also in relatively good agreement with those of other accurate methods using a burner. The flame-front instabilities of a hydrodynamic or diffusional-thermal origin are also discussed.
description.en: Experiments have been performed to determine the burning velocity of propane-air mixtures over a wide range of equivalence ratios using soap bubbles and a hot-wire anemometer. This method gives a maximum burning velocity of 50 cm/s at an equivalence ratio of 1.1. The present maximum burning velocity agrees well with the theoretical result predicted by Warnatz. The values of the burning velocity determined in these experiments are also in relatively good agreement with those of other accurate methods using a burner. The flame-front instabilities of a hydrodynamic or diffusional-thermal origin are also discussed.
